title: Photo Deconstruction: Iconic Image with 2 Strobes & 2 Gels
summary: Lindsay Adler breaks down a creative studio lighting setup to create a high-impact, colorful portrait using only two lights. The tutorial covers the specific gear used, the placement of flags to control light spill, and the post-processing steps required to correct contrast and fine-tune the color grade.

steps.action: Set up the background light using a softbox with a red gel to create a large colored light source.
Place a black flag directly behind the subject's head, in front of the softbox, to block the center light and create a rim light effect around the profile.
Set up the main light as a bare bulb with mixed blue and teal gels to illuminate the face with a complementary color.
Configure camera settings for the shot.
In post-processing, increase contrast and clarity to counteract the 'washed out' look caused by lens flare from shooting into the light.
Adjust color balance to shift greens towards blue/cyan for a more pleasing color palette.
Retouch the image by cleaning up stray hairs and extending the frame for better composition.

key_takeaways: Complex-looking rim lighting can be achieved with a single softbox blocked by a flag.
Shooting directly into a light source often reduces contrast, requiring recovery in post-production.
Mixing gels (like blue and teal) can create unique color signatures.
Simple gear (2 lights) can yield high-production value results with creative problem solving.
